subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-1622400504-1241987894=:61000
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did some tests, and =
sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing compression=
, and once turning it off.=A0=A0 I was able to verify that one was compress=
ed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once =
they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the original, a=
nd the ones sent around email.=A0 They were all identical, which indicates =
lossless compression.

If you have a file you'd like me to test for you, le=
t me know.=A0 But I wouldn't take someone's word for how your server's work=
, without testing them yourself.



--- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie =
<april@...> wrote:

From: April Abercrombie <april=
@...>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
=
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM










=

    
            
            


      
      


For executables, you may =
be right. However, 
for wav files, the compression during email is not loss=
 less. 
=A0
I used to think as you do, in that the 
emailed attachment=A0of=
 a wav file would not loose anything. After a lengthy 
discourse with anoth=
er member here, I learned that I was wrong. The reason 
why=A0I did not rea=
lize it in the first place is that when I would email a 
wav file, I would =
intentionally keep it in very small segments, to keep file 
size down. This=
 was just for ease of transfer. But because of this, I had not 
experienced=
 any noticeable loss.
=A0
Now it may be in some cases, depending on 
the se=
rvers or what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may be 
le=
ss or more. But once the attachment is 
downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has b=
een found to be less then the 
original wav.
=A0
Again though you can only =
really tell when 
the=A0wav file is large.
=A0
----- Original Message -----=
 

  From: 
  Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2=
009 1:36 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading 
  rules
  

  
  
  
 =
   
    
      The kind of compression that occurs during an email 
       =
 attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without losing 
  =
      information.=A0 For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, 
=
        and I sent it over email, it could compress it.=A0 But if it lost 
=
        even one bit, the resulting exe file would not execute again after =
it 
        was uncompressed on the other side.

This kind of compression d=
oes 
        things like looking for common patterns in the file, and repla=
cing them 
        with a token.=A0 A rough example would be if it found "H=
owdy 
        Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all the occura=
nces with 
        say $HN1.=A0 And also write a little dictionary in there=
 someplace 
        that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

When the file gets =
to its 
        destination it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $=
HN1 are 
        replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".=A0 So it was compressed (i=
nstead of 
        14 characters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionar=
y), but lost no 
        data.

Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lo=
ssless.=A0 
        Depending on the level of compression, some level of da=
ta is lost, and 
        so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
        l=
ater.

Rick



--- On Sun, 5/10/09, April 
        Abercrombie 
        <ap=
ril@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> 
        wrote:

        
From: 
      =
    April Abercrombie 
          <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
Sub=
ject: Re: 
          [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
To: 
          EVP-ITC@=
yahoogroups .com
Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 
          AM


        =
  
          
          
          Another thing:
          =A0
          I=
 recently found this out. When 
          you email a file, if it is not sa=
ved as a compressed format, the email 
          filtering process will act=
ually compress the file 
          automatically.
          =A0
          S=
o even if you have attached a 
          wav. file, it will loose resolutio=
n over the email process. It will 
          not sound exactly the same as =
the original wav. file. How much it 
          differs depends on the size =
of the file you are attaching. If it is a 
          very=A0large file, it =
will sound much different.
          =A0
          The only exception to th=
is is if 
          the wav. file is small enough that the filtering proces=
s will ignore 
          it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 1=
=A0MB (I am not 
          exactly sure of the threshold).
          =A0
  =
        The best way to share files over 
          the internet=A0if you w=
ant them as close to the original as 
          possible is to upload them =
directly to a website.
          =A0
          
            ----- 
        =
    Original Message ----- 
            From: 
            Rj 
            =
To: 
            EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
            .com 
            Sent: 
=
            Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
            Subject: 
           =
 Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
            

            
            =

            
              
              
                
Pixelization d=
oesn't clean-up the data: it 
                  replaces it.=A0 Imagine tak=
ing a picture of a field of 
                  flowers, and beginning to ad=
d levels or pixelization to the 
                  picture.=A0 Soon, you wo=
uld not be able to tell there were 
                  flowers there at all.=
=A0 You would see a lot of colored 
                  blocks.

Or in the ot=
her direction, imagine you are 
                  looking at a competely ra=
ndomize bunch of pixes on your 
                  screen: a complete screen=
 of truely random static snow.=A0 
                  Pixelizing this, after=
 a while, you would again start to see 
                  colored blocks.

=
What's happening is that it is 
                  processing an area of the=
 image, taking (for instance) the 
                  average value of that =
entire area, and replacing all the 
                  blocks in that area w=
ith the average.=A0 In video 
                  processing, this would resu=
lt in a field of multi-colored 
                  flowers being replaced by=
, for instance, a big greyish-bluish 
                  block, with no rese=
mblance to flowers.=A0 In the noise 
                  example, it maybe re=
place all the random pixels with another 
                  big greyish-blu=
ish block.=A0 If you did not know beforehand 
                  what the or=
iginal picture was, you couldn't tell whether your 
                  pixel=
ized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the 
                  s=
ky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

It works 
                  t=
he same with the sound files.=A0 Taking something as 
                  com=
plex as speech, and replacing frequencies with their 
                  ave=
rages, loses the speech the farther you go, until you head 
               =
   strange fluctuating square waves.=A0 Doing the same to 
                =
  random static will eventually produce the same thing.=A0 
               =
   And random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like 
              =
    speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing with each 
           =
       other what you thing they 'sound 
                  like'.

     =
                   
                          I always save the whole file =
in wav format then 
                          do my clips as mp3. Then I ha=
ve the original for 
                          analysis. 
                 =
         =A0
                          As far as pixelization of non sounds=
/white noise 
                          whos to say that isnt being manipul=
ated by them as 
                          well LOL. Water is a form of whi=
te noise. I seem to 
                          remember some experiments do=
ne with blank tapes/film, 
                          no recording=A0done ye=
t there were voices/images 
                          there. I find it all =
interesting.
                          =A0
                          Just a=
 thought. Ok off to work now!
                          Misty

--- On Sun, =
5/10/09, Rj 
                          <rasterer@yahoo. com> 
wrote:

     =
                     
From: 
                            Rj <rasterer@yahoo=
. com>
Subject: Re: 
                            [EVP-ITC] File uploading r=
ules
To: 
                            EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
Date: Sunday=
, May 10, 
                            2009, 11:47 AM


                   =
         
                            
                            
       =
                     
                              
                      =
        
                                Be a bit careful of formats like 
=
                                mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of=
 the 
                                sounds though.=A0=A0 While some forma=
ts 
                                (like wav) can store the audio very clo=
se to the 
                                way it was recorded, formats lik=
e mp3 compress 
                                the file, and in so doing l=
ose some of the sonic 
                                details.=A0 This may=
 not be a big deal in 
                                music, where the aud=
io is fairly clear to begin 
                                with.=A0 But w=
ith sound sources with a lot of 
                                noise (lik=
e evps), this can not only obscure any 
                                rea=
l sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                            =
    noise) and make them start to sound like 
                             =
   speech.

So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                             =
   the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
                       =
         based on an analysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
                    =
            mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.=A0 
                 =
               It can lead to many false positives and 
                   =
             misinterpretations.

     <tr>
                <td valign=3D"top"><br>Pixelization doesn't clean=
-up the data: it 
                  replaces it.  Imagine taking a pic=
ture of a field of 
                  flowers, and beginning to add levels =
or pixelization to the 
                  picture.  Soon, you would no=
t be able to tell there were 
                  flowers there at all. =
 You would see a lot of colored 
                  blocks.<br><br>Or in the=
 other direction, imagine you are 
                  looking at a competely=
 randomize bunch of pixes on your 
                  screen: a complete scr=
een of truely random static snow.  
                  Pixelizing this,=
 after a while, you would again start to see 
                  colored blo=
cks.<br><br>What's happening is that it is 
                  processing an=
 area of the image, taking (for instance) the 
                  average va=
lue of that entire area, and replacing all the 
                  blocks in=
 that area with the average.  In video 
                  processing, =
this would result in a field of multi-colored 
                  flowers be=
ing replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish 
                  bloc=
k, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise 
                  ex=
ample, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another 
               =
   big greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know beforehand 
        =
          what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether your 
  =
                pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the=
 
                  sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.<br><br>It=
 works 
                  the same with the sound files.  Taking somet=
hing as 
                  complex as speech, and replacing frequencies wit=
h their 
                  averages, loses the speech the farther you go, u=
ntil you head 
                  strange fluctuating square waves.  Do=
ing the same to 
                  random static will eventually produce th=
e same thing.  
                  And random fluctuating square waves =
can sound a bit like 
                  speech - or at least, you could hav=
e fun sharing with each 
                  other what you thing they 'sound=
 
                  like'.<br><br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, M=
isty

                          whos to say that isn=

                          well LOL. Water i=

rding done yet there were voices/images

 <tr>
                                <td valign=3D"top">Be a bit careful o=
f formats like 
                                mp3 if you are doing a deta=
iled analysis of the 
                                sounds though. &=
nbsp; While some formats 
                                (like wav) can st=
ore the audio very close to the 
                                way it was=
 recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
                                the f=
ile, and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
                              =
  details.  This may not be a big deal in 
                           =
     music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin 
                     =
           with.  But with sound sources with a lot of 
              =
                  noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
       =
                         real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
=
                                noise) and make them start to sound like 
 =
                               speech.<br><br>So mp3 might be good for shar=
ing 
                                the data, once you've already formed a=
n opinion 
                                based on an analysis of the wav =
file.  But 
                                mp3 is not good as a mediu=
m for analysis.  
                                It can lead to many =
false positives and 
                                misinterpretations.<br=
